title: The Glass Nobody Knows About
body:
Every TV on the planet starts with this machine.

It takes molten glass at 2,000 degrees and pulls it into sheets thinner than a credit card. No touching. No polishing. Just gravity.

One company makes almost all of it. Corning. Ticker GLW. Up 76% this year.
cta: Next time we're looking at the chip inside every PlayStation! This is Becknology where markets meet machines.

title: Your Oreo Travels 1,000 Miles
body:
This machine makes 25,000 Oreos per minute.

The cream gets injected at exactly 3.5 grams -- every single cookie. One factory runs 24/7 and ships to 100 countries.

The company behind it? Mondelez. Ticker MDLZ. JP Morgan says it's worth $69.
cta: Stick around, we've got aluminum cans next! This is Becknology where markets meet machines.

title: Every Can You've Ever Opened
body:
100 billion aluminum cans get made every year. This is the machine that does it.

A flat aluminum disc gets punched, stretched, and shaped into a can in under a second. 2,400 cans per minute. One machine.

The company that dominates? Ball Corporation. Ticker BALL. They make 1 in 4 cans on Earth.
cta: Stick around, we've got razors next! This is Becknology where markets meet machines.

title: The Razor Blade Factory
body:
A single razor blade gets 14 separate processes before it touches your face.

Hardened steel, laser-cut, coated in chromium, then platinum, then a polymer. Each blade edge is 700 atoms wide.

Procter & Gamble owns Gillette. Ticker PG. Warren Buffett's been holding it for decades.
cta: Follow along, next time is the machine that makes toilet paper at a hundred miles per hour! This is Becknology where markets meet machines.

title: PlayStation's Secret Weapon
body:
Every PlayStation camera, every iPhone face unlock -- same company.

Sony makes 50% of the world's image sensors. Not the phones. Not the cameras. The tiny chip inside that actually captures the light.

Ticker SONY. Analysts say 41% upside from here. Most people only think of them as a gaming company.
cta: Next time we're looking at the stock behind the internet! This is Becknology where markets meet machines.

title: Toilet Paper at 100 MPH
body:
This machine turns wood pulp into toilet paper at 100 miles per hour.

The paper gets pressed, dried, creped for softness, and wound onto rolls -- all in one continuous line. One factory makes enough for 50 million people per year.

Procter & Gamble. Ticker PG. They make Charmin, Bounty, and Puffs -- all on machines like this.
cta: Follow along, next time we're looking at the stock behind the internet! This is Becknology where markets meet machines.

title: Who Actually Makes Your Internet Work
body:
This cable carries 800 terabits per second. Enough to stream every Netflix show simultaneously.

Fiber optic cable. Hair-thin glass threads carrying data at the speed of light. And one company makes more of it than anyone else.

Corning. Same company that makes your TV glass. Ticker GLW. Data centers can't scale without them.
cta: Next time, the machine inside every Amazon box! This is Becknology where markets meet machines.

title: The Machine Inside Every Amazon Box
body:
2 billion packages a year. Every one needs a box. This is how they're made.

Corrugated cardboard -- three layers bonded at 350 degrees, cut and folded by machines running 24/7. One factory outputs 1 million boxes a day.

Packaging Corp of America. Ticker PKG. E-commerce can't exist without them.
cta: Stick around, next up is what's actually inside your energy drink! This is Becknology where markets meet machines.

title: What's Actually Inside Your Energy Drink
body:
Red Bull, Monster, Celsius -- they all use the same can.

Aluminum. Recycled in 60 days. Cooled faster than glass. Lighter to ship than plastic. And Ball Corporation makes a quarter of every can on the planet.

Ticker BALL. The drink brand doesn't matter. The can company always wins.
cta: Next time, the robot that replaced 800 workers! This is Becknology where markets meet machines.

title: The Robot That Replaced 800 Workers
body:
Amazon has 750,000 robots in its warehouses. This one moves 1,000 packages per hour.

It sees, picks, sorts, and routes -- no human needed. Five years ago this job took a team of 800 people per shift.

The robots come from companies like Fanuc and Rockwell. Automation is eating logistics.
cta: Follow along, next time we're looking at the glass nobody knows about! This is Becknology where markets meet machines.
